X-eGroups-Approved-By: vbossica <vladimir@...> via web; 24 May 2005 00:27:20 -0000

Actually, we do test accessor methods using a Verification 
Facillitator ( http://sourceforge.net/projects/testutil/ ).

At this point, I'm actually more interested in organizational 
reporting as follows:

Organizations that *do* attempt to fire getters/setters: What is the
strategy? Are these all hand-coded?  Are these organizations 
attempting to achieve (and report) near-100% code coverage?

Organizations that *do not* attempt testing these methods: How do
they report their code coverage? For instance, do they "back-out"
the amount of code represented by getters/setters and then report the
percentage of remaining code covered? Or - do they lower the goal to
something considerably less than 100%?

Is anyone actually striving for (and reporting metrics toward) near-
100% code coverage?

_Marvin

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> y153446 wrote:
> > I'm interested in best practices around automated unit testing 
of 
> > getters and setters for organizations striving for near-100% 
code 
> > coverage.
> > Is anyone actually striving for near-100% code coverage?
> > 
> 
> Yes. Getters and setters are easy to test. Test them! You'll be 
> surprised how many bugs you'll find in methods that are supposedly 
too 
> simple to fail.
> 
> There are a few cases where you really can't test stuff. In 
particular 
> Sometimes you just have to have unreachable code. For instance, I 
> sometimes find myself implementing an interface such as 
> java.util.Iterator in a private inner class. My private 
implementation 
> may never call remove() but I still need to implement that method 
anyway 
> to fulfill the contract of Iterator. Normally I just make the 
method 
> throw an exception, in case I'm wrong and something does call it. 
> However, there's just no way to reach it to test it (nor is there 
any 
> need to do so since this code will never run.) But aside from a 
few 
> weird cases like that, all code should be tested or deleted.
> 
> -- 
> Elliotte Rusty Harold  elharo@m...
